lesson.title: Polishing Dashboards for Production
lesson.summary: In this lesson, students will learn how to design the final dashboard by attending to the text hierarchy, affordance, interactivity of the dashboard, annotations, and color scheme.

atoms.text:
## Lesson Outline

Welcome to lesson 3. In this lesson we’ll be learning how to polish dashboards for production. We’ll be doing this by breaking down the concepts of: Color, Interactivity and Annotations to add style, move the users through your work and clearly explain what matters and why.

So, here again are the topics we will cover in this lesson.
1.  Color
2.  Interactivity
3.  Annotations

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A03 Color V2
Color
atoms.text:
Color is difficult to do well. 

The following tools can be used to help make better decision about the choice of color in your visualization. 

This tool provides a very small selection of color palettes. Provides you with the options of ensuring the colors are color blind friendly and that there is enough contrast for people to easily distinguish between one color and another.

* [Color Brewer](http://colorbrewer2.org/#type=sequential&scheme=BuGn&n=5)
* [Data Wrapper](https://blog.datawrapper.de/colorguide/)
* [Viz Palette](https://projects.susielu.com/viz-palette) cited above in the video was developed by Susie Lu and Elijah Meeks, Senior data visualization engineers at Netflix. Please visit the website to use the tool.

Here is a tool developed by Cynthia Brewer to help us make better decision and avoid common mistakes.
[Cynthia’s tool](http://colorbrewer2.org/#type=sequential&scheme=BuGn&n=5) provides a very small, but useful selection of palettes. You can ensure colors are color blind friendly with the check of a box while also making sure there’s enough contrast between the discrete color categories.
You can also use color to grab the audience's attention. This can be done by muting everything other than the point you want them to pay attention to, such as in the example below.

atoms.title: Few roles for plays for visualization
atoms.text:
#### Colors help with each of these:
* Encoding
* Mood
* Identity


In the next few pages, we will cover each of these in depth.

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A-- Color Is Hard V2
ND197 C2 L3 A05 Encoding V2

atoms.text:
Useful resources
* [Color palette generator Link 1](https://www.canva.com/colors/color-palette-generator/)
* [Color palette generator Link 2](https://coolors.co)
### Quiz

question.text: How are we using color to encode meaning in the above visualization?

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Here is one way color is being used. The intensity of the color red is used to indicate the intensity of the love interests across the various countries. Because there is only one numeric measure (love interest) needing to be encoded we address this with a single hue. Furthermore, since we’re talking about love it’s fitting to use the color red.

question.text: How are we using color to encode meaning in the above visualization?`

answer.text:
Thanks for your response. So here are one set of thoughts.
Different colors (or hues) encode the different races in this area chart. Race is an ordinal variable here, so we need to avoid a color ramp as well as any colors that grab stand out more than the others. We want the data to tell the story and color to simply support our ability to interpret the visuals.

question.text: How are we using color to encode meaning in the above visualization?

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Different colors are used to distinguish the cohorts. So the way we are using color here is to have the different green colored dots depict the changes between the two years. Importantly, when the difference is significantly greater for the same month, we use a darker green color, whereas a lighter green color is used when the difference is significantly less for the same month.

atoms.text: # Solution

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A10 Quiz 1 Solution V2
ND197 C2 L3 A17 Cultures See Colors Differently V2
Cultures and Color
atoms.text:
Color has the potential to convey more meaning than what might be derived from the data alone. 

Check out the following links that highlight how different cultures from around the world might perceive the same color very differently.

For example, when depicting the topic of death for a Western audience, you may choose to use black as your color choice. However, in more eastern cultures,  white is more fitting.

Other useful resources to check out on the topic of color:
[Creativebloq.com](https://www.creativebloq.com/web-design/12-colours-and-emotions-they-evoke-61515112)

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A19 Coloring KPIs V2

atoms.text:
Key performance measure or indicators (KPI) can also be depicted visually using colors as well.  I’d argue the color these visual is important. This is particularly relevant if the KPI needs to be indicated as having positive or negative reference. Often these visuals are depicted in two-colors to **encode** a binary positive/negative meaning, but the **color ranges** is a factor here too. 

Check out the following links that highlight this point of using specific colored dots and font color is used to draw attention to specific metrics. Contrasting colors can also be used to distinguish the positive and negative outcome:
[Adam McCann's dashboard](https://public.tableau.com/en-us/s/gallery/20-ways-visualize-kpis)

## Check out these tools to quickly brand a dashboard Check out the following links that depict how color is essential for branding:
* [Colorzilla extension](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/colorzilla/bhlhnicpbhignbdhedgjhgdocnmhomnp?hl=es-419) * [Quick color scheme picker](https://coolors.co/) [Palette](https://www.canva.com/colors/color-palette-generator/)

complex_prompt.text: What color is the brand? Think about why company is using that color, what is their origin history?

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A-- Demo Pulling Color From Brands Or Pictures V2
ND197 C2 L3 A24 Common Color Mistakes V2
ND197 C2 L3 A25 Dual Encoding V2

atoms.text:
### What is Dual Encoding?

Dual encoding is redundant encoding. In other words, encoding for the same measure using multiple ways. It is not a practice we encourage. As described in the demo above, dual encoding can be confusing.

Check out this work by researchers at Northwestern University: Christine Nothelfer, Michael Gleicher, and Steven Franconeri that nicely captures [dual encoding challenges](http://visualthinking.psych.northwestern.edu/projects/papers/Nothelfer,%20Gleicher,%20&%20Franconeri%20-%20Redundant%20Encoding.pdf)

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A30 Challenge Encoding With Color V2
ND197 C2 L3 A33 Color Blindness V2
Color blindness text
atoms.text:
## Color Blindness

When visualizing, use color to communicate information to our audience that might perceive colors differently than us. A few years ago there was a big media story about a blue dress causing confusion? People could not understand whether it was blue or black?

Color perception isn’t something most people think about often. It’s something that happens in the way it occurs.

Here are some interesting facts about the occurrence of color blindness in the wider population. These are things to pay attention to when designing effective dashboards.

* Eight percent of males are thought to have color blindness? Color blindness is most commonly due to? Genetics
* Red-green is the most common color sensation deficiency
* Color  blindness affects ~8% of the male population and ~0.005% of the female population
* Sub Saharan Africans having been found to have the lowest % of color blindness

Here are some links you can explore to test for color blindness:
* Testing for [color blindness](https://www.fastcompany.com/90168112/viz-palette-the-ultimate-tool-for-anyone-who-works-with-color)
* Testing your [own color blindness](https://www.colour-blindness.com/colour-blindness-tests/ishihara-colour-test-plates/)
* [Color blindness](https://www.color-blindness.com/2009/01/19/colorblind-colors-of-confusion/)
* [NIH resource](https://nei.nih.gov/health/color_blindness/facts_about)
* [Color blindness awareness](http://www.colourblindawareness.org/colour-blindness/)
We have provided some tools below for making colors accessible. The Color Palettes tools are used to identify the correct color.

atoms.title: Tools Link
atoms.text:
### Accessibility
* [Viz Palette](https://projects.susielu.com/viz-palette)
* [WebAIM](https://webaim.org/resources/contrastchecker/)
* [Color Oracle](https://colororacle.org/index.html)

### Palettes
* [Canva Palette](https://www.canva.com/colors/color-palette-generator/)
* [I want hue](http://tools.medialab.sciences-po.fr/iwanthue/)
* [Adobe Colors](https://color.adobe.com/create)
* [Colors](https://coolors.co/)
* [Color Brewer](http://colorbrewer2.org/#type=sequential&scheme=BuGn&n=5)

### Inspiration
* [Pinterest](http://pinterest.com/)
* [Dribbble](https://dribbble.com/colors/8930e8)
* [Behance](https://www.behance.net/)
* [Picking palettes](https://blog.graphiq.com/finding-the-right-color-palettes-for-data-visualizations-fcd4e707a283)

## Exercise 1. 

####  Instructions:
Your task is to download this image and brand this dashboard.
You can use the following color style guide from Udacity.
Here is my take on branding this image.

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A41 Interactivity V2
Interactivity
atoms.text:
If our visualizations were static we wouldn’t care. Static visualization are like painting hanging on a museum wall. Their effectiveness depends on how the audience decides to view the artists work on that day. But, of course, exploratory visualizations depend on the data on that day, how the users chose to explore it and the designer designed the flow.

https://public.tableau.com/profile/robert.crocker#!/vizhome/MMWeek2/FallingSales

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A44 Interaction Design V3 Fix
Interaction design
atoms.text:
## Interaction Design

You don’t want your users aimlessly scanning the screen in search of the right button to click. You need to send a signal so they know what is to be clicked or hovered or panned.

Here are some resources that you may find useful as you explore ways to highlight interaction design:
* The bible on design by Don Normal is a must-read: Design Everyday Things
* [Boxes and Arrows](http://boxesandarrows.com/introducing-interaction-design/)
* [Interaction design](https://www.uxbooth.com/articles/complete-beginners-guide-to-interaction-design/)
* John Stasko's paper titled "Toward a Deeper Understanding of the Role of Interaction in Information Visualization" is also a highly recommended read.

Overall, as I see it, it is our job as dashboard designers to help users achieve their goals in as frustration free a way as possible. In order to choreograph the best interaction dance one needs deep knowledge of both the actors and the stage.

atoms.title: Affordance
atoms.text:
## Affordance by Don Norman
“Affordances define what actions are possible. Signifiers specify how people discover those possibilities: signifiers are signs, perceptible signals of what can be done. Signifiers are of far more importance to designers than are affordances.” [Donald A. Norman, The Design of Everyday Things: Revised and Expanded Edition, 2013, pXIV-XV]

## Four Principles of Affordance
There are four principles of affordance that are important to keep in mind as a visual designer.
Follow convention
Support visuals with text
Build on metaphors, use text
Be consistent create a coherent model

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A49 Interaction Types V2
ND197 C2 L3 A-- Interactions As Targets V2

atoms.text:
## Interactivity

Example of common interaction types:
Button click
Mark selection
Drill down
Connected visuals

You don’t want your users aimlessly scanning the screen in search of the right button to click. You need to send a signal so they know what is to be clicked or hovered or panned. If there’s room to spell out the instructions for them, go ahead.

Here are some resources you can explore on relevant topics:
* [CTA colors](https://smallbusiness.yahoo.com/advisor/truth-best-worst-call-action-button-colors-website-212506540.html)
* [SDG](https://public.tableau.com/profile/robert.crocker#!/vizhome/workspace/MMWeek36)

Our main goal here is usability. You want your audience to understand what they’re looking at and what they need to do to draw out the information they need to get to their goal.

question.text:
Quiz: What are some common types of interaction
* Click
* Hover
* Scroll
* Pinch
* Shake X
* Squeeze X

atoms.text: # Solution

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A51 Interactivity Quiz Solution V2
ND197 C2 L3 A53 Fitt S Law V2

atoms.text:
## Fitt’s Law

In the context of dashboard design, this law makes it clear to me that our design can bias how users interact with our dashboard. Unless that bias is warranted we need to be conscious of how our designs can impact the interactions people has with the pieces we create.

* [Fitt’s Law](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/article/fitts-s-law-the-importance-of-size-and-distance-in-ui-design)
* Good article on [touch targets](https://medium.com/@zacdicko/size-matters-accessibility-and-touch-targets-56e942adc0cc)

How are you users going to interact with your dashboard? Finger, mouse, stylus, other?

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A57 Schneiderman S Mantra V2
Link to Schneiderman's Mantra
atoms.text:
One framework you’ll hear about over and over as you get deeper into dashboard design is the Schneiderman Mantra. 
Here is a resource to learn more about it: [http://www.codingthearchitecture.com](http://www.codingthearchitecture.com/2015/01/08/shneidermans_mantra.html)

### Here are some tools on annotations that you may find useful.

[Chart Accent](https://chartaccent.github.io/)
[Susie Lu’s website](https://d3-annotation.susielu.com/) provides a nice introduction to this topic

#### In the image 1 in the video, the following legend is used  to depict the annotation anatomy 
1. Take away (or action) title, Title case link
2. Date range + more context around the measures used
3. Describes the horizontal axis as simply as possible
4. Calls out key points in the data and associates itself with a specific line
5. Labels each of the lines and creates an association between the color and that category
6. Calls out the datasource and author


#### In the second image, here is the list of annotation references.
1. Take away (or action) title, Title case link
2. Date range + more context around the measures used
3. Describes the horizontal axis as simply as possible
4. Calls out key points in the data and associates itself with a specific line
5. Labels each of the lines and creates an association between the color and that category
6. Calls out the datasource and author

## Annotation Layer ### Here are some resources we recommend: * Medium post by [Urban Institute about annotations](https://medium.com/@urban_institute/three-ways-to-annotate-your-graphs-d140e04e48ec) * Blog on [Visualization Annotation](http://www.ambriente.com/blog/2015/02/24/amanda-cox-at-columbia-university/) ### Annotation should include:
  1. Chart labels
  2. Legends
  3. Marks
  4. Sections of a chart
    Making it as easy as possible for you audience to understand the data and visualization is always appreciated
  5. Active titles
    In explanatory viz I see a lot of takeaway titles or active titles, but in dashboards I think it’s better to use the question our chart is meant to address as the title
  6. Adding detail
    Adding specifics can help your audience understand the point you’re trying to make “The annotation layer is really where the journalism comes into the visual journalism.”

## Adding labels to your charts
* Legends
* Marks
* Sections of a chart
Making it as easy as possible for you audience to understand the data and visualization is always appreciated
Active titles: It is better to use the question our chart is meant to address as the title, especially in dashboards

## Adding detail
This [blog post](https://medium.com/@urban_institute/three-ways-to-annotate-your-graphs-d140e04e48ec) provides a nice summary of different ways to annotate

atoms.title: ND197 C2 L3 A-- UK General Election Example V2
Appropriate context
atoms.text:
## What provides appropriate context?

Make sure to list the following to provide full context for the content of your dashboard.
<ol>
<li>Name of the datasource
<li>Contact for questions
<li>Critical calculations
<li>Who built the dashboard
<li>Who else contributed in a meaningful way
<li>Who to contact with questions
<li>The full date range
<li>List latest how recently the data was refreshed
<li>The next time the data will be refreshed 
<li>Calculations details and/or Units of Measure

#### A good question to ask yourself is “How could someone get confused by this?

atoms.title: Exercise_3
atoms.text: ## What needs to be added to make sure the context is clear

atoms.title: Other considerations
atoms.text:
## Other Considerations regarding Text

* Alignment
* Fonts
* Font-weight
* Color
* Size 
 *Text hierarchy. 

It is now time to organize the text intuitively in our display. This could be alignment, fonts, font-weight, color, and size are just a few things to think about. One tool we’ll leverage heavily is a text hierarchy. It is best to keep it simple with one color and maybe only a couple fonts (one purely for text and the other for KPIs and the like). When differentiating text from one another don’t change too much from one style to another. 

## Examples of Annotation
 Check out the various dashboards designed by visual designers on [vizforsocialgood.com](https://www.vizforsocialgood.com/our-work).

question.text:
## What needs to be added to make sure the context is clear?
The examples shared in the course all presented a subtitle with more detailed explanatory text, clear axes, information in the footer, and details where appropriate. In this exercise students should apply what they learned about annotations in the previous examples to clear up any uncertainty here or simply add context so users can navigate the dashboard with confidence.

answer.text:
A few helpful annotations to be added are…

1. Subtitle summarizing the dashboard
2. Helpful column names mentioning a category
3. Text stating what the big numbers refer to
4. Labels over the line to make the numbers more specific
5. Axes on the bar charts so the user can see the range of values
6. A footer mentioning where the data comes from


* Designer
Who originally created the dashboard
* Data source
Where is the data coming from
* Refresh schedule
When was the data last refreshed and when will it be refreshed next.
* Date range
Of the data fed into this dashboard, how much time does it span?
* Calculation information
Are their any calculations that could be confusing to someone new to this tool. If so, it’s helpful to reference resources where the users can learn how the measures are calculated and/or why it’s done this way.
* Legend to say what the darker grey bars indicate (optional)
Color encodings without clear labels need a legend in order for users to understand their meaning.
* Who to contact with questions
If possible provide a sort of support number or contact people can reach out to with questions
